answer: When we think of immortality, we often think how easy life would be. We would have time for everything, but that is just one part. The other we do not think is, we should have enough money to be able to eat, or how would the aging of our body work, would we age till 50 year old body and then live or 20 year old body, or 80 year old body. Depending on that we could suffer or we could have the time of our lives.

answer: Not always, as it can hurt people who are not ready for the truth.
feedback: You identified a key aspect of honesty's complexity. Improve: Consider providing examples or scenarios to deepen your argument.

answer: As I am a realistic person, I like to know an ugly truth because then I can earlier start learning more about the problem and be more ready for future problems. The comforting lie just makes me happy for that moment, at the end I will probably feel sad and maybe even more sad than if I have learned the truth immediatelly
feedback: Great job articulating the benefits of facing the truth! Improve: Consider adding a personal example to deepen your argument.

answer: People lie to themselves for many reasons, some of them are not being able to look themselves in the mirror or being lazy. Both are just moving the problem from today to tomorrow, but with probably higher consequences. To not lie to ourselves when it is hard, it is a brave thing to do, as it is hard to get on with your feeling and not just let it go and go with the flow.
feedback: Great insight into the challenges of self-deception and the bravery it takes to confront reality. Improve: Expand on the reasons to add depth and clarity.

answer: A lie can be moral only if it is for good purpose of people or person you are telling to. But the problem is you cannot perfectly know if the person will get good purpose out of getting a lie and not truth. It is important to think from other peoples perspective and then you can figure out if you should lie. Also, it is always good idea to tell the truth and then if it is a really bad truth or the person could outlive the truth, than it is morally okay to lie.
feedback: Great job exploring the complexities of morality in lying! Improve: Clarify your examples to strengthen your argument on when lying might be justified.

answer: It can be only moral if you can justify that the person you are telling the lie is going to be better if he does not hear the truth at the moment. For a long run, it would better to always tell the truth, so the person can be realistic about things that are heppening around him, and be able to fix them as soon as possible.
feedback: Great insight on the potential benefits of lies in specific situations! Improve: Clarify examples where a lie might be justified to enhance depth and understanding.
